text: um you know a lot of people are saying
you heard this this week that well we
seem to be in some kind of pulum shift
where uh there have been a lot of
concerns about safety and what's
happened in the past is we'll go through
this phase where people were worried
about the safety of drugs on the market
and after a while the concerns about
access to medicines go back up and we
have a pulum shift um back the other way
I don't think it's going to quite work
out that way um this time I think we're
really in kind of a different era of
sensitivity about safety issues when
reason for that is that there is a lot
more information available than there
ever has been before about potential
safety problems um we now have data from
clinical trials maybe not completely
available but much more widely available
than ever before through clinical
trials.gov we have a lot of data that
are being developed and used by sources
other than the manufacturers and in the
olden days um postmarket data came from
drug manufacturers now a lot of the
postmarket data comes from health plans
and pbms and employ ERS and Medicare uh
other sources of evidence that are not
uh directly controlled and related uh to
the manufacturers themselves and it is
not hard these days to do um just a
straightforward statisical analysis and
show that hey there's some association
between the use of a drug and an adverse
outcome and we're going to see a lot
more of that and we've uh seen a number
of these kinds of reports in the past
few years uh some of which have really
amounted to something doesn't mean that
they always will but it does mean that
we're at a different level of public
concern and awareness about safety
issues and really is incumbent on uh the
federal government and all of us who are
involved in the healthcare industry to
do a better job of understanding and
responding to those
concerns
